title: 115_s27
content: An independent commission called the "Commission to End Russian Interference in United States Elections" is established to address the issue. The Commission's functions will focus on ending Russian interference in US elections. The Commission will investigate Russian cyber operations and interference in the 2016 US election, including attempts to tamper with electronic voting systems and political organizations. The investigation will examine Russian efforts to generate propaganda relevant to the 2016 US elections and collaborate with other governments or entities to carry out these activities. The investigation will examine attempts by governments, entities, and individuals to influence US elections in 2016 using electronic means. It will also evaluate evidence from various government agencies regarding Russia's interference in the same elections. The investigation will review completed and ongoing efforts to investigate Russian interference in the 2016 US election, including inquiries by the Obama Administration, Senate Intelligence Committee, Senate Armed Services Committee, Senate Foreign Relations Committee, and other entities. It will also account for official and unofficial attempts to interfere in the election through cyber operations. The Commission will assess interference in the US election, including cyber operations and propaganda, evaluate government preparedness, and report findings to prevent future interference. The Commission will assess interference in the US election, including cyber operations and propaganda, evaluate government preparedness, and report findings to prevent future interference. SEC. 3. COMPOSITION. The Commission, composed of eight members appointed by Senate and House leaders, must be appointed within 30 days of the Act's enactment and serve for the Commission's duration. Members must have political party diversity. The Commission, composed of eight members appointed by Senate and House leaders, must have political party diversity. Not more than 4 members can be from the same political party. Members cannot be Members of Congress, federal government employees, or state/local government employees. Individuals appointed should be prominent US citizens with experience in various professions. The Commission, consisting of eight members appointed by Senate and House leaders with political party diversity, must select a Chairperson and Vice-Chairperson from different parties within 60 days of enactment. Six members constitute a quorum, and vacancies do not affect the Commission's power and duties. Vacancies on the Commission do not affect its power and duties and must be filled within 90 days. The Commission has powers outlined in Section 4. The Commission, after its initial meeting, can hold hearings, receive evidence, administer oaths, and subpoena witnesses and documents as necessary to carry out its functions under Section 2. The Commission can issue subpoenas under the agreement of the Chairperson and Vice-Chairperson or by a vote of 5 members. Subpoenas can be issued under the signature of the Chairperson or a designated member. The Commission can issue subpoenas under the agreement of the Chairperson and Vice-Chairperson or by a vote of 5 members. Subpoenas can be enforced through a court order in case of non-compliance. The Commission can issue subpoenas, and failure to comply may result in court punishment for contempt. If a witness still fails to comply, the Commission can certify the failure to the US attorney for further action. The Commission can issue subpoenas and certify non-compliance to the US attorney for further action. Federal agencies must provide access to necessary information for the Commission to carry out its functions. The Commission can access information controlled by federal agencies and must handle it according to regulations. The General Services Administration provides office space and administrative support for the Commission's activities. Other departments and agencies may also assist as needed. The Commission can receive assistance from other Federal departments and agencies, including services, funds, facilities, staff, and support services. They are also authorized to use the United States mails and enter into contracts with various entities. The Commission can receive assistance from Federal departments and agencies, including services, funds, facilities, staff, and support services. They can also enter into contracts with various entities for necessary activities, with a termination date specified in section 10. The Commission can receive assistance from Federal departments and agencies, including staff support. The Commission shall have a Director appointed by majority vote, paid at a rate not exceeding level IV of the Executive Schedule. The Director can appoint staff with approval, paid at the same rate. Additional staff can be appointed as needed to carry out duties. The Commission can appoint experts and consultants for temporary services at rates not exceeding level IV of the Executive Schedule. Federal Government employees can also be detailed to the Commission upon request. Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement, retaining their rights and privileges of regular employment. The Commission is not subject to the Federal Advisory Committee Act, will hold public meetings and release reports, and conduct public hearings while protecting sensitive information. Compensation and travel expenses for government employees detailed to the Commission are covered. SEC. 7. COMPENSATION AND TRAVEL EXPENSES. Members of the Commission serve without pay and are not considered Federal employees. They are allowed travel expenses in accordance with regulations. SEC. 8. SECURITY CLEARANCES FOR COMMISSION MEMBERS AND STAFF. SEC. 8. Security clearances for Commission members and staff are to be provided expeditiously by Federal agencies in accordance with existing procedures. Access to classified information under this Act requires appropriate security clearances. The Commission must submit a report to various committees within 18 months of its first meeting, detailing recommendations and findings. The report must include detailed recommendations, findings, and conclusions from the Commission, as well as summaries of input and recommendations from consulted leaders and organizations. It will be submitted in an unclassified form for public availability, with the possibility of a classified annex. The Commission will terminate 60 days after submitting its report to Congress as per section 9.
